author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Sudan’s military releases the prime minister.
content: Abdalla Hamdok, Sudan’s prime minister, returned to power on Sunday, four weeks after he was ousted in a military coup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Thanksgiving Will Cost More This Year. That Could Cost Democrats, Too.
description: Rising prices for gas and a holiday meal could come back to bite Democrats, who fear that inflation may upend their electoral prospects in the 2022 midterms.
content: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Samantha Martin, a single mother shopping ahead of Thanksgiving, lamented how rising gas and grocery prices have eaten away at the raise she got this year as a manager at McDonald’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Playwright Is in Exile as Cuba Uses an Old Playbook to Quash Dissent
description: Yunior García, a rising star of the Cuban protest movement, fled to Spain. He is one of a young generation of artists who say they have chosen exile over imprisonment.
content: MADRID — For Yunior García, a Cuban playwright, the swift journey from activism in Havana to exile in Madrid might have been lifted from one of his scripts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: The Very Idea!
description: Stella Zawistowski has another puzzle in the books.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — How fun to see the constructor Stella Zawistowski, maker of some notoriously challenging indie puzzles, back in the New York Times Crossword with a nice, breezy Monday!
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Saw a Passenger Stand When the Train Got to DeKalb Avenue’
description: Monday morning on the B, moving to Manhattan and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Myra Noveck
title: Israeli Is Killed by Palestinian Near Holiest Site in Jerusalem
description: The shooting, the first attack by a Palestinian since May to result in the death of a Jewish civilian, could deepen tensions within Israel’s fragile governing coalition.
content: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian teacher shot dead an Israeli tour guide with an automatic gun near the holiest site in Jerusalem on Sunday morning, Israeli officials said. It was the first killing of a Jewish Israeli civilian by a Palestinian gunman since May.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
title: In Hard Times, Afghan Farmers Are Turning to Opium for Security
description: The war’s intense conclusion and a drought combined to wipe out the famous Afghan pomegranate harvest in Kandahar Province, during a devastating national economic crisis.
content: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan — Abdul Hamid’s pomegranate trees were scarred from bullets and shrapnel. The river was low and the land dry. There was no profit anymore from the fruit that made his district in southern Afghanistan so renowned for something other than war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Met Opera’s Next ‘Ring’ Will Be a Sea Change
description: Richard Jones’s bleak staging of Wagner’s “Die Walküre” in London offers a clean break from the extravagance of the Met’s most recent production.
content: LONDON — It’s never a good idea for a critic to make predictions, but I’ll venture one: When the Metropolitan Opera’s next staging of Wagner’s epic “Der Ring des Nibelungen” arrives in New York in a few years, there won’t be any stories about the set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Review: ‘The Alchemist,’ a Play in Search of Comedy Gold
description: Red Bull Theater brings on the cons and their marks in this adaptation of the 17th-century Ben Jonson work.
content: Let’s face it: Some people don’t just ask to be conned, they practically beg for it. Their greed, be it for money, sex or power, makes them vulnerable to the most extraordinary fabrications: the more outlandish the promises, the harder they fall for them. Conveniently, their hubris and self-confidence shelter them from the fact that they are gullible idiots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Zverev Shuts Down Djokovic, Will Meet Medvedev in the ATP Tour Finals
description: The world No. 1 is increasingly under threat on hardcourts from younger, taller players — like the two men who will play in the finals on Sunday.
content: TURIN, Italy — There will be no record-tying sixth victory in the ATP Finals for Novak Djokovic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson
title: How the U.S. Lost Ground to China in the Contest for Clean Energy
description: Americans failed to safeguard decades of diplomatic and financial investments in Congo, where the world’s largest supply of cobalt is controlled by Chinese companies backed by Beijing.
content: WASHINGTON — Tom Perriello saw it coming but could do nothing to stop it. André Kapanga too. Despite urgent emails, phone calls and personal pleas, they watched helplessly as a company backed by the Chinese government took ownership from the Americans of one of the world’s largest cobalt mines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Kate Kelly
title: G.O.P. Donors Back Manchin and Sinema as They Reshape Biden’s Agenda
description: The two Democratic senators are attracting campaign contributions from business interests and conservatives as progressives fume over their efforts to pare back the president’s domestic policy bill.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the summer, as he was working to scale back President Biden’s domestic agenda, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia traveled to an $18 million mansion in Dallas for a fund-raiser that attracted Republican and corporate donors who have cheered on his efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Utah Dominates Oregon, Upending Pac-12’s Playoff Hopes
description: The third-ranked Ducks fell on the road, the second loss for the Pac-12’s best team.
content: SALT LAKE CITY — The Oregon Ducks had toppled fearsome Ohio State on the road at the Horseshoe. They had navigated their Pac-12 Conference schedule and stumbled just once, in overtime, at Stanford. They rose to become the nation’s third-ranked team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Weighs In on the Kyle Rittenhouse Verdict
description: This weekend’s broadcast, hosted by Simu Liu, also included some helpful Thanksgiving tips and, uh, Dog Head Man.
content: About a half-hour into this weekend’s broadcast, “Saturday Night Live” would devote an entire sketch to a character with a dog’s head and neck attached to a human body. But first, the show addressed the acquittal of Kyle Rittenhouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Suspect’s Family Helps Crack Unsolved Killing From 1959
description: The murder of 9-year-old Candice Rogers rocked Spokane, Wash. On Friday, the police identified John Reigh Hoff as a suspect, and said his daughter helped them solve the case.
content: One Friday afternoon in 1959, Candice Rogers came home from school, played with her dog, ate an oatmeal cookie and then set out to sell Camp Fire mints in her neighborhood in Spokane, Wash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Kasakove
title: Family of Elijah McClain to Receive $15 Million in Settlement
description: Mr. McClain, a young Black man, died in 2019 after being restrained by the police in Aurora, Colo.
content: Officials in Aurora, Colo., finalized an agreement on Friday to pay $15 million to the family of Elijah McClain to settle a federal civil rights lawsuit over the police confrontation in 2019 that ended his life, according to city officials and the family’s lawyer. Mr. McClain, a 23-year-old Black man, died after the police in that city restrained him with a chokehold maneuver that has since been banned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: How Do You Make Teen Comedies Today? Buy a High School.
description: A former school outside Syracuse, N.Y., has been transformed into American High, a production hub for inexpensive films aimed at streaming platforms.
content: LIVERPOOL, N.Y. — The teenage couple is lounging on the lawn outside a high school, taking advantage of a free period between classes in that age-old way: making out on the quad. A friend runs over, clearly agitated by a drama unfolding elsewhere, and asks for help. The duo reluctantly gets up and follows, dragging their backpacks behind them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Binder and Mark Spindel
title: Biden’s Fed Pick Could Prove His Commitment to Bipartisanship
description: Joe Biden’s pick to head the Federal Reserve is coming down to Jay Powell or Lael Brainard.
content: Amid price pressure, Republican attacks and voter angst, President Biden will soon reveal his choice to lead the Federal Reserve, the agency charged by Congress with a dual mandate to maximize employment with stable prices while maintaining a sound financial system. By most accounts, Mr. Biden is considering another four-year term for Republican lawyer Jerome Powell, the current chair, or promoting his colleague, Democratic economist Lael Brainard, a Fed official and former Obama administration treasury official. His choice will be a test of his commitment to bipartisanship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Malone
title: How to Get Past ‘Did Not Finish’
description: Some marathon runners end up with a final result listed as D.N.F. Getting back to the start line of another race can be that much more meaningful.
content: Leah Ofsevit had long dreamed of running the Boston Marathon. A native of Newton, Mass., she had finished three other marathons before and had qualified for the 2018 installment of the Boston race, which she proudly calls her hometown marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: Disney puts worker vaccine mandate on pause after Florida ban on restrictions.
description: Iconic brand runs into political headwinds over the pandemic response.
content: Disney has put on pause a coronavirus vaccine mandate for employees of its Florida theme park after the State Legislature and the governor made it illegal for employers to require all workers get the shots, a company spokesperson confirmed Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: A Robot Wrote This Book Review
description: In “The Age of AI,” Henry Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher explore how far artificial intelligence has come.
content: THE AGE OF AIAnd Our Human FutureBy Henry A. Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: After a Year Off, and an Off Year, Ivy League Crowns Familiar Champions
description: The only Division I league to not play football last season because of the pandemic, the Ivy League endured an unusual journey of virus disruptions in its return.
content: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The Ivy League football standings don’t look much different this season: Dartmouth and Princeton, one of which had earned at least a share of four of the last five championships, did so again after Saturday’s season finale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 22, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Why Democrats’ ‘Talking Points Are Not Enough’
description: The House progressive spoke about “demoralizing” congressional negotiations, how she was told to stay away from Virginia’s elections, and what it means to excite the Democratic base.
content: Last year, after Joseph R. Biden Jr. won the Democratic presidential nomination, a group of progressive lawmakers rallied around him to project party unity at a critical time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: With a Second ATP Finals Win, Alexander Zverev Proves He Is Rising
description: This year gave the 24-year-old German star six singles titles, Olympic gold, an ATP Finals trophy, but also an ongoing tour investigation into allegations of physical abuse against a former girlfriend.
content: TURIN, Italy — It was about the match at hand on Sunday as Alexander Zverev confidently rumbled to his second career title at the ATP Finals with a 6-4, 6-4 victory over Daniil Medvedev.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Homans
title: To Paramilitary Groups, Rittenhouse Verdict Means Vindication
description: His acquittal has reinvigorated support on the right for armed responses to racial justice protests and unrest.
content: On Friday, as Kyle Rittenhouse stood in a courtroom in Kenosha, Wis., awaiting the verdict in his trial, a large bald man with mutton chop sideburns sat in a pew several rows behind him. As a court clerk announced Mr. Rittenhouse’s acquittal on all charges, a faint smile passed across the man’s lips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: As Soldiers Abandon Notorious Myanmar Army, a Morale Crisis Looms
description: The number of defectors, while not enough to topple the Tatmadaw, is growing, galvanized by the nationwide anti-coup movement.
content: Aung Myo Htet had always dreamed of being a soldier, and had attained the rank of captain. But when he joined the army in Myanmar, he had thought he would be defending his country, not fighting — and losing — pitched battles against his own countrymen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Islanders Are Finally Home Sweet Home
description: The N.H.L. team lost its first game at the new $1.1-billion UBS Arena but they lost in style. The seats are comfy, the concourses spacious and the bathrooms big and numerous enough that fans won’t miss any goals.
content: As an eighth grader, Ray Larkin went with his family to the first New York Islanders game ever. It was October 1972, at Nassau County Coliseum and Larkin went on to see hundreds more games there over the next five decades, most as a season-ticket holder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: The Nets Are Winning, but They Still Have a Lot to Figure Out
description: They’re winning when they should but struggling against teams they’ll probably see in the playoffs. They miss Kyrie Irving, but that doesn’t explain everything.
content: The Nets are in the middle of an identity crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Who, and Where, Is Peng Shuai?
description: A blackout within China on discussion of the tennis star’s #MeToo allegations has not been able to silence a global chorus of concern for her safety.
content: A simple question has gripped the sports world and drawn the attention of the White House, United Nations and others:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Hair Curlers in Public? That’s Just How They Roll.
description: The young South Korean women who wear them say they are not only functional, but also a sign of shifting ideas about beauty and a reflection of the country’s generational divide.
content: SEOUL — In a subway car on a recent fall afternoon, seven young South Korean women stood quietly among a crowd of commuters. They wore seasonal jackets and wind breakers just like other passengers, but one accessory made them stand out: old-fashioned hair curlers locked tightly into their bangs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: With Another Loss, the Jets Look for Silver Linings
description: Are the Jets watchable yet? No, but Elijah Moore sure is.
content: Our N.F.L. playoffs calculator has an up-to-date look at the latest playoff picture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Ousted in Coup, Sudan’s Prime Minister Returns via Military Deal
description: Four weeks after he was detained, Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok struck a deal to end a bloody standoff in the streets. Protesters rejected the move as a “betrayal.”
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — After four weeks under house arrest, Sudan’s ousted prime minister was reinstated on Sunday after he signed a deal with the military intended to end a bloody standoff that led to dozens of protester deaths and threatened to derail Sudan’s fragile transition to democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib
title: Two of 17 Kidnapped Missionaries in Haiti Are Freed, Group Says
description: After being held hostage for 37 days by a gang, two people with a U.S. Christian aid group have been released in Port-au-Prince and are described as “safe.”
content: Two of the 17 people with an American missionary group who were kidnapped in Haiti more than a month ago have been released, the organization said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Two Fox News Contributors Quit in Protest of Tucker Carlson’s Jan. 6 Special
description: Jonah Goldberg and Stephen Hayes, stars of a brand of conservatism that has fallen out of fashion, decide they’ve had enough.
content: The trailer for Tucker Carlson’s special about the Jan. 6 mob at the Capitol landed online on Oct. 27, and that night Jonah Goldberg sent a text to his business partner, Stephen Hayes: “I’m tempted just to quit Fox over this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Solskjaer Out at Manchester United After a Loss Too Far
description: Lopsided defeats against Liverpool and Manchester City had the one-time fan favorite teetering. A humbling loss at lowly Watford finished him off.
content: Manchester United had not done it after a humiliation by Liverpool. And the club’s executives had managed to tolerate the sight of Manchester City’s cruising to victory at Old Trafford while barely breaking a sweat. After each defeat, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, the manager who had overseen both calamities, somehow remained in his post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Ardeshir Zahedi, Irrepressible Iranian Diplomat, Dies at 93
description: While he enabled business deals worth billions of dollars, he also hosted lavish parties, led conga lines through his embassy and dated Elizabeth Taylor.
content: Ardeshir Zahedi, who as Iran’s ambassador to the United States hosted some of Washington’s most lavish, star-studded parties and derived his cachet in part from his closeness to the shah, died on Thursday in exile at his villa in the lakeside town of Montreux, near Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Vancouver Is Marooned by Flooding and Besieged Again by Climate Change
description: After a summer of deadly heat and uncontrolled wildfires, British Columbia was hit by record rainfalls that forced the evacuation of towns and destroyed highways and rail lines.
content: The intense rains and heavy winds that descended last week on British Columbia, the Canadian province known for its mountains, coastline and majestic forests, forced 17,000 people from their homes, emptying entire towns and inundating farms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooke Jarvis, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo and Marion Lozano
title: The Sunday Read: ‘Did Covid Change How We Dream?’
description: All around the world, the pandemic provoked strange nocturnal visions. Can they help shed light on the question of why we dream at all?
content: As the novel coronavirus spread and much of the world moved toward isolation, dream researchers began rushing to design studies and set up surveys that might allow them to access some of the most isolated places of all, the dreamscapes unfolding inside individual brains. The first thing almost everyone noticed was that for many people, their dream worlds seemed suddenly larger and more intense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Gerrymanders Get Worse, Legal Options to Overturn Them Dwindle
description: Persuading judges to undo skewed political maps was never easy. A shifting judicial landscape is making it harder.
content: Voting-rights advocates are in a North Carolina state court in Raleigh this month, arguing in three lawsuits that Republican gerrymanders of the State Legislature and the state’s 14 seats in the House of Representatives are so extreme that they violate the state Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Gas Prices, Covid, Thanksgiving Recipes: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Video of Peng Shuai With Olympic Officials Fuels a Showdown With Tennis
description: The Chinese tennis star held a 30-minute video call with the leader of the International Olympic Committee, but the head of women’s professional tennis remained unable to reach her.
content: Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star who disappeared from public life for more than a week after she accused a former top government official of sexual assault, appeared in a live video call with the president of the International Olympic Committee and other officials with the organization on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey and Roser Toll Piraffé
title: As Pandemic Evictions Rise, Spaniards Declare ‘War’ on Wall Street Landlords
description: Protesters in Barcelona are pushing back against foreign investment firms that have bought up thousands of homes over the past decade and are forcing out residents who can’t pay the rent.
content: BARCELONA, Spain — Ana María Banegas lives on a sun-drenched street in central Barcelona, a short walk from where her children go to school. Outside, a doormat welcomes visitors: “Home Sweet Home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: More Asian countries slowly reopen their borders and welcome vaccinated travelers.
description: The easing of restrictions comes as the holiday travel season is about to begin.
content: As Asian countries are learning to live with the coronavirus — with the notable exception of China — and gaining momentum in their vaccination campaigns, several are cautiously reopening their borders and welcoming travelers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
title: José Antonio Kast, Far-Right Candidate, Leads After First Round of Chile’s Presidential Election
description: The top contenders to lead Chile out of a turbulent era are a leftist 35-year-old former student activist and a 55-year-old far-right former congressman, offering voters a stark choice.
content: SANTIAGO, Chile — Chileans on Sunday gave the lead in the country’s presidential race to a far-right politician, a stunning development in a nation that has been rattled by political and social protest over inequality and the rising cost of living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: New York’s Midcentury Art Scene Springs to Life in ‘The Loft Generation’
description: Edith Schloss’s memoir recounts an era of great creative vitality and the time she spent with Willem and Elaine de Kooning, Merce Cunningham, Leo Castelli and others.
content: Many prophesied the demise of New York City during the Great and Temporary Exodus of 2020. But none had quite the dramatic vision of Jack Tworkov, the abstract expressionist painter, in the middle of the previous century. “Imagine a great catastrophe. And all this mowed down,” he mused then, looking at photographs of buildings, envisioning rust and dust. “And tourists wandering around in all that emptiness — where was the Flatiron, the Empire State — looking for past grandeur. Imagine good old New York someday just like Egypt.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Covid-19 surge strains Michigan’s hospitals.
description: Staffing shortages and pandemic fatigue add to complications.
content: Many hospitals in Michigan are nearing their capacities amid an alarming surge in coronavirus cases.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vaccine’s Arrival in South Sudan Is Cold Comfort
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 21, 2021.
content: “We heard people are dying, but we haven’t seen anyone sick here. When you are starving, you don’t think about other things — you need to feed your stomach first.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: He Sold Away His People’s Heritage. He’s in the Jungle to Get It Back.
description: A Cambodian temple looter, who says more than 100 artifacts he stole are in museums around the world, is working to help reclaim them.
content: As Toek Tik recounts it, he was a teenage foot soldier for the genocidal Khmer Rouge in Cambodia in the late 1970s when he first realized that looting ancient statues could be a lucrative trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian J. Rivera
title: Just Because You Don’t Believe in Conspiracy Theories Doesn’t Mean You’re Always Right
description: From the Salem witch trials to the Astroworld disaster, conspiracy theories and reformist narratives have battled for dominance in the American consciousness.
content: Every so often, something so awful and senseless happens that it’s hard to fully absorb it. An apartment building collapses as residents sleep within. A movie star’s prop gun fires a real bullet on a film set, killing a young mother. A concert crowd morphs into a melee that leaves people dead and injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Angry and Divided, Austrians Argue Over a Lockdown and Vaccine Mandates
description: As a new wave of Covid infections spreads over Europe, resistance to public health measures is growing, and not just in Austria.
content: VIENNA — Daniel Zeman wasn’t able to sell any of his handmade apple-ginger liqueur last year during the Christmas season because Austria, along with the rest of Europe, was in lockdown. He finally opened his stand four days ago, only to have the government announce that Sunday would be the last day. Austria was locking down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Víctor Manuel Ramos
title: A Canadian senator has died after being hospitalized for Covid.
description: Josée Forest-Niesing, a Canadian senator from Ontario, died shortly after she went home from a hospital where she had been treated for Covid-19, Canadian officials said Saturday. She was 56.
content: Josée Forest-Niesing, a Canadian senator from Ontario, died shortly after she went home from a hospital where she had been treated for Covid-19, Canadian officials said Saturday. She was 56.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Five Ways to Exercise Your Thankfulness Muscles
description: Feeling grateful does not always happen naturally.
content: I’m from a family that doesn’t talk much about feelings. We keep it mostly to jokes, sarcasm and sports. When I was growing up, perhaps the biggest perceived sin was being overly earnest and sincere. So all of us kids were shocked when one Thanksgiving, out of nowhere, my parents announced that we’d begin a new ritual. The 20 to 30 of us gathered for the Thanksgiving meal each had to share something we were grateful for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Biden’s Safety Net Package Clears One Hurdle
description: The president signed the $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill. Retail sales are up and signs point to a strong holiday season. And the next Fed chair could be named any day.
content: On Monday, President Biden signed a $1.2 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill into law. Though not as ambitious as the $2.3 trillion plan he proposed, it provides billions for improvements to roads, ports and power lines and to increase access to broadband internet and replace hazardous lead drinking pipes. The fate of a separate $2 trillion spending package focused on climate change, early childhood education and a wide range of social policy initiatives remains in flux. Opponents say it will worsen inflation. (The Biden administration has argued it will reduce inflation by making businesses and workers more productive.) And the Congressional Budget Office said on Thursday that the package would increase the federal budget deficit by $160 billion over the next 10 years. On Friday, the social safety net bill narrowly passed the House but now faces a difficult path ahead in the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Lara Jakes
title: As Hopes for Nuclear Deal Fade, Iran Rebuilds and Risks Grow
description: With Iran’s new administration preparing for its first international nuclear negotiations, there are signs that there will be no going back to the 2015 agreement.
content: WASHINGTON — Over the past 20 months, Israeli intelligence operatives have assassinated Iran’s chief nuclear scientist and triggered major explosions at four Iranian nuclear and missile facilities, hoping to cripple the centrifuges that produce nuclear fuel and delay the day when Tehran’s new government might be able to build a bomb.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 21, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 21, 2021.
content: An article on Nov. 14 about the real estate market in Austin, Texas, misspelled the names of two of that city’s suburbs. They are Pflugerville and Buda, not Pfluggerville and Butta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Eric Lipton
title: Mining Congo: A Global Power Play
description: The Democratic Republic of Congo has been a critical source of strategic minerals for the United States since at least World War II.
content: The Democratic Republic of Congo has been a critical source of strategic minerals for the United States since at least World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The World Cup Is a Year Away. Who’s In?
description: The field for Qatar 2022 is starting to take shape. Here’s a look at where things stand so far.
content: The field for Qatar 2022 is starting to take shape. Here’s a look at where things stand so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Some tips for thawing turkey and a road map for meals that aren’t Thanksgiving-themed.
content: Good morning. This is a big day for Thanksgiving preparations, if you don’t want to make like me and Melissa Clark, who once on a dare cooked the whole meal in a single eight-hour push.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lincoln vs. the Constitution? Not So Fast.
description: Lincoln, the Emancipation Proclamation and the Constitution. Also: A call for gratitude; arena as metaphor; disparate energy burdens.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
